subject: Art & Design
title: Color vs. Black and White: When to Choose
description: A micro-lesson that makes Color vs. Black and White: When to Choose usable.

hook.text: Some photos are stronger in black and white. Color would distract from the real subject: form and emotion.

buildup.text: Color adds information: mood, season, warmth. It's rich but can compete with the subject.

discovery.text: Black and white strips a scene to essentials: light, shadow, shape, and texture.

twist.text: Don't convert to B&W to 'save' a bad color photo. B&W demands strong tonal contrast to work.

climax.text: Shoot in color, convert later. You keep both options and can decide based on the story each version tells.

punchline.text: Color shows the world. Black and white shows the feeling.

quiz.question: When does black and white photography work best?
options: When the story is about form, emotion, and tonal contrast
When the camera can't capture color
